messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

Always use the programming language the user asks for.
Default to use Python when not specified where applicable.
Always write python tests with the prefix `test_`.
For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
For NodeJS, you always create an appropriate package.json file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses

Objective:```
**Online Microblogging Service (OMS) - Description & Requirements**

*Description:*  
A web-based platform where registered users can post short text-based messages, view messages from others, follow/unfollow other users, and interact with posts. The platform provides features for both individual users and administrative management.

**1. User Management:**
1.1. **Registration & Authentication:**  
- Allow users to register using email, username, and password.
- Option to reset forgotten passwords.
- Secure authentication using JWT or similar protocols.

1.2. **Profile Management:**  
- Users can edit their profile information: profile picture, bio, website link, and location.
- Option to make profile private or public.

**2. Posting & Content Management:**
2.1. **Creating Posts (Tweets):**  
- Allow users to create text-based posts with a limit of 280 characters.
- Option to include images posts.
- Users can delete their own posts.

2.2. **Interacting with Posts:**  
- Users can like, retweet, and reply to posts.
- Nested comment structure for post replies.

2.3. **Content Filtering & Search:**  
- Users can search for specific posts or users using keywords.
- Filter option based on hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics.

**3. Social Interaction:**
3.1. **Following & Followers:**  
- Users can follow/unfollow other users.
- A timeline view displays posts from followed users.
- Users receive notifications for new followers.

3.2. **Direct Messaging:**  
- Private conversation threads between users.
- Option to block/unblock users from messaging.

3.3. **Notifications:**  
- Users are notified of likes, retweets, replies, and mentions.

**4. Trending & Discovery:**
4.1. **Trending Topics:**  
- System identifies and displays trending hashtags or topics based on volume and velocity of mentions.
- Trending topics can be sorted based on location or globally.

4.2. **User Recommendations:**  
- Recommend users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers.

```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.

function_call.name: provide_detailed_sub_task_steps_for_sub_agents
function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "1. Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new directory for the project and initialize it as a Python project. Create subdirectories for the different components of the project: 'models', 'controllers', 'views', 'tests', and 'utils'. In the root directory, create a 'main.py' file which will serve as the entry point for the application. Also, create a 'requirements.txt' file to list all the Python packages that will be needed for the project. Some of the packages that will be needed include Flask (for building the web application), SQLAlchemy (for ORM), PyJWT (for JWT authentication), pytest (for testing), and Pillow (for image processing).",

    "2. Define the data models for the application. In the 'models' directory, create Python files for each of the following models: 'user.py', 'post.py', 'comment.py', 'like.py', 'follow.py', 'message.py', 'notification.py', and 'trend.py'. Each of these files will define a class that represents a table in the database. For example, the 'user.py' file will define a User class with attributes such as id, email, username, password, profile_picture, bio, website_link, location, and is_private. The 'post.py' file will define a Post class with attributes such as id, user_id, text, image, and timestamp. The 'comment.py' file will define a Comment class with attributes such as id, user_id, post_id, text, and timestamp. The 'like.py' file will define a Like class with attributes such as id, user_id, and post_id. The 'follow.py' file will define a Follow class with attributes such as follower_id and followee_id. The 'message.py' file will define a Message class with attributes such as id, sender_id, receiver_id, text, and timestamp. The 'notification.py' file will define a Notification class with attributes such as id, user_id, type, and related_id. The 'trend.py' file will define a Trend class with attributes such as id, hashtag, count, and timestamp. After defining these classes, write tests to ensure that instances of these classes can be created, saved to the database, retrieved, updated, and deleted.",

    "3. Implement the controllers for the application. In the 'controllers' directory, create Python files for each of the following controllers: 'user_controller.py', 'post_controller.py', 'comment_controller.py', 'like_controller.py', 'follow_controller.py', 'message_controller.py', 'notification_controller.py', and 'trend_controller.py'. Each of these files will define a class that contains methods for handling the different operations related to the corresponding model. For example, the 'user_controller.py' file will define a UserController class with methods such as register, login, reset_password, edit_profile, and toggle_privacy. The 'post_controller.py' file will define a PostController class with methods such as create_post, delete_post, and search_posts. The 'comment_controller.py' file will define a CommentController class with methods such as create_comment and delete_comment. The 'like_controller.py' file will define a LikeController class with methods such as like_post and unlike_post. The 'follow_controller.py' file will define a FollowController class with methods such as follow_user and unfollow_user. The 'message_controller.py' file will define a MessageController class with methods such as send_message, receive_messages, and block_user. The 'notification_controller.py' file will define a NotificationController class with methods such as get_notifications and mark_as_read. The 'trend_controller.py' file will define a TrendController class with methods such as get_trending_hashtags and get_user_recommendations. After implementing these classes, write tests to ensure that the methods work as expected.",

    "4. Implement the views for the application. In the 'views' directory, create Python files for each of the following views: 'user_view.py', 'post_view.py', 'comment_view.py', 'like_view.py', 'follow_view.py', 'message_view.py', 'notification_view.py', and 'trend_view.py'. Each of these files will define a class that contains methods for rendering the corresponding views. For example, the 'user_view.py' file will define a UserView class with methods such as register, login, reset_password, edit_profile, and toggle_privacy. The 'post_view.py' file will define a PostView class with methods such as create_post, delete_post, and search_posts. The 'comment_view.py' file will define a CommentView class with methods such as create_comment and delete_comment. The 'like_view.py' file will define a LikeView class with methods such as like_post and unlike_post. The 'follow_view.py' file will define a FollowView class with methods such as follow_user and unfollow_user. The 'message_view.py' file will define a MessageView class with methods such as send_message, receive_messages, and block_user. The 'notification_view.py' file will define a NotificationView class with methods such as get_notifications and mark_as_read. The 'trend_view.py' file will define a TrendView class with methods such as get_trending_hashtags and get_user_recommendations. After implementing these classes, write tests to ensure that the views render correctly and the user interactions are handled properly.",

    "5. Implement the main application. In the 'main.py' file, import the Flask module and create an instance of the Flask class. Also, import the views and register them with the Flask application. Set up the routes for the different views and the corresponding HTTP methods. For example, the route for the register view might be '/register' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the login view might be '/login' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the reset_password view might be '/reset_password' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the edit_profile view might be '/edit_profile' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the toggle_privacy view might be '/toggle_privacy' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the create_post view might be '/create_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the delete_post view might be '/delete_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the search_posts view might be '/search_posts' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the create_comment view might be '/create_comment' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the delete_comment view might be '/delete_comment' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the like_post view might be '/like_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the unlike_post view might be '/unlike_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the follow_user view might be '/follow_user' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the unfollow_user view might be '/unfollow_user' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the send_message view might be '/send_message' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the receive_messages view might be '/receive_messages' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the block_user view might be '/block_user' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the get_notifications view might be '/get_notifications' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the mark_as_read view might be '/mark_as_read' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the get_trending_hashtags view might be '/get_trending_hashtags' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the get_user_recommendations view might be '/get_user_recommendations' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. After setting up the routes, write tests to ensure that the routes work as expected and the HTTP methods are handled properly.",

    "6. Implement the utility functions for the application. In the 'utils' directory, create Python files for each of the following utilities: 'auth.py', 'image.py', 'search.py', 'trend.py', and 'recommend.py'. The 'auth.py' file will define functions for handling authentication, such as generating and verifying JWT tokens. The 'image.py' file will define functions for processing images, such as resizing and cropping. The 'search.py' file will define functions for searching posts and users. The 'trend.py' file will define functions for identifying trending hashtags and topics. The 'recommend.py' file will define functions for recommending users to follow. After implementing these utilities, write tests to ensure that they work as expected.",

    "7. Finally, run the application and perform end-to-end testing. Use the pytest module to run all the tests that have been written. Ensure that all the tests pass. If any tests fail, debug the code and fix the issues. Once all the tests pass, the application is ready for deployment."
  ]
}

steps: 1. Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new directory for the project and initialize it as a Python project. Create subdirectories for the different components of the project: 'models', 'controllers', 'views', 'tests', and 'utils'. In the root directory, create a 'main.py' file which will serve as the entry point for the application. Also, create a 'requirements.txt' file to list all the Python packages that will be needed for the project. Some of the packages that will be needed include Flask (for building the web application), SQLAlchemy (for ORM), PyJWT (for JWT authentication), pytest (for testing), and Pillow (for image processing).

2. Define the data models for the application. In the 'models' directory, create Python files for each of the following models: 'user.py', 'post.py', 'comment.py', 'like.py', 'follow.py', 'message.py', 'notification.py', and 'trend.py'. Each of these files will define a class that represents a table in the database. For example, the 'user.py' file will define a User class with attributes such as id, email, username, password, profile_picture, bio, website_link, location, and is_private. The 'post.py' file will define a Post class with attributes such as id, user_id, text, image, and timestamp. The 'comment.py' file will define a Comment class with attributes such as id, user_id, post_id, text, and timestamp. The 'like.py' file will define a Like class with attributes such as id, user_id, and post_id. The 'follow.py' file will define a Follow class with attributes such as follower_id and followee_id. The 'message.py' file will define a Message class with attributes such as id, sender_id, receiver_id, text, and timestamp. The 'notification.py' file will define a Notification class with attributes such as id, user_id, type, and related_id. The 'trend.py' file will define a Trend class with attributes such as id, hashtag, count, and timestamp. After defining these classes, write tests to ensure that instances of these classes can be created, saved to the database, retrieved, updated, and deleted.

3. Implement the controllers for the application. In the 'controllers' directory, create Python files for each of the following controllers: 'user_controller.py', 'post_controller.py', 'comment_controller.py', 'like_controller.py', 'follow_controller.py', 'message_controller.py', 'notification_controller.py', and 'trend_controller.py'. Each of these files will define a class that contains methods for handling the different operations related to the corresponding model. For example, the 'user_controller.py' file will define a UserController class with methods such as register, login, reset_password, edit_profile, and toggle_privacy. The 'post_controller.py' file will define a PostController class with methods such as create_post, delete_post, and search_posts. The 'comment_controller.py' file will define a CommentController class with methods such as create_comment and delete_comment. The 'like_controller.py' file will define a LikeController class with methods such as like_post and unlike_post. The 'follow_controller.py' file will define a FollowController class with methods such as follow_user and unfollow_user. The 'message_controller.py' file will define a MessageController class with methods such as send_message, receive_messages, and block_user. The 'notification_controller.py' file will define a NotificationController class with methods such as get_notifications and mark_as_read. The 'trend_controller.py' file will define a TrendController class with methods such as get_trending_hashtags and get_user_recommendations. After implementing these classes, write tests to ensure that the methods work as expected.

4. Implement the views for the application. In the 'views' directory, create Python files for each of the following views: 'user_view.py', 'post_view.py', 'comment_view.py', 'like_view.py', 'follow_view.py', 'message_view.py', 'notification_view.py', and 'trend_view.py'. Each of these files will define a class that contains methods for rendering the corresponding views. For example, the 'user_view.py' file will define a UserView class with methods such as register, login, reset_password, edit_profile, and toggle_privacy. The 'post_view.py' file will define a PostView class with methods such as create_post, delete_post, and search_posts. The 'comment_view.py' file will define a CommentView class with methods such as create_comment and delete_comment. The 'like_view.py' file will define a LikeView class with methods such as like_post and unlike_post. The 'follow_view.py' file will define a FollowView class with methods such as follow_user and unfollow_user. The 'message_view.py' file will define a MessageView class with methods such as send_message, receive_messages, and block_user. The 'notification_view.py' file will define a NotificationView class with methods such as get_notifications and mark_as_read. The 'trend_view.py' file will define a TrendView class with methods such as get_trending_hashtags and get_user_recommendations. After implementing these classes, write tests to ensure that the views render correctly and the user interactions are handled properly.

5. Implement the main application. In the 'main.py' file, import the Flask module and create an instance of the Flask class. Also, import the views and register them with the Flask application. Set up the routes for the different views and the corresponding HTTP methods. For example, the route for the register view might be '/register' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the login view might be '/login' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the reset_password view might be '/reset_password' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the edit_profile view might be '/edit_profile' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the toggle_privacy view might be '/toggle_privacy' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the create_post view might be '/create_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the delete_post view might be '/delete_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the search_posts view might be '/search_posts' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the create_comment view might be '/create_comment' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the delete_comment view might be '/delete_comment' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the like_post view might be '/like_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the unlike_post view might be '/unlike_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the follow_user view might be '/follow_user' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the unfollow_user view might be '/unfollow_user' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the send_message view might be '/send_message' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the receive_messages view might be '/receive_messages' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the block_user view might be '/block_user' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the get_notifications view might be '/get_notifications' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the mark_as_read view might be '/mark_as_read' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the get_trending_hashtags view might be '/get_trending_hashtags' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the get_user_recommendations view might be '/get_user_recommendations' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. After setting up the routes, write tests to ensure that the routes work as expected and the HTTP methods are handled properly.

6. Implement the utility functions for the application. In the 'utils' directory, create Python files for each of the following utilities: 'auth.py', 'image.py', 'search.py', 'trend.py', and 'recommend.py'. The 'auth.py' file will define functions for handling authentication, such as generating and verifying JWT tokens. The 'image.py' file will define functions for processing images, such as resizing and cropping. The 'search.py' file will define functions for searching posts and users. The 'trend.py' file will define functions for identifying trending hashtags and topics. The 'recommend.py' file will define functions for recommending users to follow. After implementing these utilities, write tests to ensure that they work as expected.

7. Finally, run the application and perform end-to-end testing. Use the pytest module to run all the tests that have been written. Ensure that all the tests pass. If any tests fail, debug the code and fix the issues. Once all the tests pass, the application is ready for deployment.

Objective:```
**Online Microblogging Service (OMS) - Description & Requirements**

*Description:*  
A web-based platform where registered users can post short text-based messages, view messages from others, follow/unfollow other users, and interact with posts. The platform provides features for both individual users and administrative management.

**1. User Management:**
1.1. **Registration & Authentication:**  
- Allow users to register using email, username, and password.
- Option to reset forgotten passwords.
- Secure authentication using JWT or similar protocols.

1.2. **Profile Management:**  
- Users can edit their profile information: profile picture, bio, website link, and location.
- Option to make profile private or public.

**2. Posting & Content Management:**
2.1. **Creating Posts (Tweets):**  
- Allow users to create text-based posts with a limit of 280 characters.
- Option to include images posts.
- Users can delete their own posts.

2.2. **Interacting with Posts:**  
- Users can like, retweet, and reply to posts.
- Nested comment structure for post replies.

2.3. **Content Filtering & Search:**  
- Users can search for specific posts or users using keywords.
- Filter option based on hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics.

**3. Social Interaction:**
3.1. **Following & Followers:**  
- Users can follow/unfollow other users.
- A timeline view displays posts from followed users.
- Users receive notifications for new followers.

3.2. **Direct Messaging:**  
- Private conversation threads between users.
- Option to block/unblock users from messaging.

3.3. **Notifications:**  
- Users are notified of likes, retweets, replies, and mentions.

**4. Trending & Discovery:**
4.1. **Trending Topics:**  
- System identifies and displays trending hashtags or topics based on volume and velocity of mentions.
- Trending topics can be sorted based on location or globally.

4.2. **User Recommendations:**  
- Recommend users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses

Objective:```
**Online Microblogging Service (OMS) - Description & Requirements**

*Description:*  
A web-based platform where registered users can post short text-based messages, view messages from others, follow/unfollow other users, and interact with posts. The platform provides features for both individual users and administrative management.

**1. User Management:**
1.1. **Registration & Authentication:**  
- Allow users to register using email, username, and password.
- Option to reset forgotten passwords.
- Secure authentication using JWT or similar protocols.

1.2. **Profile Management:**  
- Users can edit their profile information: profile picture, bio, website link, and location.
- Option to make profile private or public.

**2. Posting & Content Management:**
2.1. **Creating Posts (Tweets):**  
- Allow users to create text-based posts with a limit of 280 characters.
- Option to include images posts.
- Users can delete their own posts.

2.2. **Interacting with Posts:**  
- Users can like, retweet, and reply to posts.
- Nested comment structure for post replies.

2.3. **Content Filtering & Search:**  
- Users can search for specific posts or users using keywords.
- Filter option based on hashtags, user mentions, or trending topics.

**3. Social Interaction:**
3.1. **Following & Followers:**  
- Users can follow/unfollow other users.
- A timeline view displays posts from followed users.
- Users receive notifications for new followers.

3.2. **Direct Messaging:**  
- Private conversation threads between users.
- Option to block/unblock users from messaging.

3.3. **Notifications:**  
- Users are notified of likes, retweets, replies, and mentions.

**4. Trending & Discovery:**
4.1. **Trending Topics:**  
- System identifies and displays trending hashtags or topics based on volume and velocity of mentions.
- Trending topics can be sorted based on location or globally.

4.2. **User Recommendations:**  
- Recommend users to follow based on interests, activity, and mutual followers.

```

Understand the problem, by creating an extremely detailed detailed step-by-step plan, where each step is long (multiple sentences) and in total includes every single feature requirement specified above, feel free to copy directly from it. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass. Please be sure to include all of the specified feature requirements in the following plan.

function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "1. Start by setting up the project structure. Create a new directory for the project and initialize it as a Python project. Create subdirectories for the different components of the project: 'models', 'controllers', 'views', 'tests', and 'utils'. In the root directory, create a 'main.py' file which will serve as the entry point for the application. Also, create a 'requirements.txt' file to list all the Python packages that will be needed for the project. Some of the packages that will be needed include Flask (for building the web application), SQLAlchemy (for ORM), PyJWT (for JWT authentication), pytest (for testing), and Pillow (for image processing).",

    "2. Define the data models for the application. In the 'models' directory, create Python files for each of the following models: 'user.py', 'post.py', 'comment.py', 'like.py', 'follow.py', 'message.py', 'notification.py', and 'trend.py'. Each of these files will define a class that represents a table in the database. For example, the 'user.py' file will define a User class with attributes such as id, email, username, password, profile_picture, bio, website_link, location, and is_private. The 'post.py' file will define a Post class with attributes such as id, user_id, text, image, and timestamp. The 'comment.py' file will define a Comment class with attributes such as id, user_id, post_id, text, and timestamp. The 'like.py' file will define a Like class with attributes such as id, user_id, and post_id. The 'follow.py' file will define a Follow class with attributes such as follower_id and followee_id. The 'message.py' file will define a Message class with attributes such as id, sender_id, receiver_id, text, and timestamp. The 'notification.py' file will define a Notification class with attributes such as id, user_id, type, and related_id. The 'trend.py' file will define a Trend class with attributes such as id, hashtag, count, and timestamp. After defining these classes, write tests to ensure that instances of these classes can be created, saved to the database, retrieved, updated, and deleted.",

    "3. Implement the controllers for the application. In the 'controllers' directory, create Python files for each of the following controllers: 'user_controller.py', 'post_controller.py', 'comment_controller.py', 'like_controller.py', 'follow_controller.py', 'message_controller.py', 'notification_controller.py', and 'trend_controller.py'. Each of these files will define a class that contains methods for handling the different operations related to the corresponding model. For example, the 'user_controller.py' file will define a UserController class with methods such as register, login, reset_password, edit_profile, and toggle_privacy. The 'post_controller.py' file will define a PostController class with methods such as create_post, delete_post, and search_posts. The 'comment_controller.py' file will define a CommentController class with methods such as create_comment and delete_comment. The 'like_controller.py' file will define a LikeController class with methods such as like_post and unlike_post. The 'follow_controller.py' file will define a FollowController class with methods such as follow_user and unfollow_user. The 'message_controller.py' file will define a MessageController class with methods such as send_message, receive_messages, and block_user. The 'notification_controller.py' file will define a NotificationController class with methods such as get_notifications and mark_as_read. The 'trend_controller.py' file will define a TrendController class with methods such as get_trending_hashtags and get_user_recommendations. After implementing these classes, write tests to ensure that the methods work as expected.",

    "4. Implement the views for the application. In the 'views' directory, create Python files for each of the following views: 'user_view.py', 'post_view.py', 'comment_view.py', 'like_view.py', 'follow_view.py', 'message_view.py', 'notification_view.py', and 'trend_view.py'. Each of these files will define a class that contains methods for rendering the corresponding views. For example, the 'user_view.py' file will define a UserView class with methods such as register, login, reset_password, edit_profile, and toggle_privacy. The 'post_view.py' file will define a PostView class with methods such as create_post, delete_post, and search_posts. The 'comment_view.py' file will define a CommentView class with methods such as create_comment and delete_comment. The 'like_view.py' file will define a LikeView class with methods such as like_post and unlike_post. The 'follow_view.py' file will define a FollowView class with methods such as follow_user and unfollow_user. The 'message_view.py' file will define a MessageView class with methods such as send_message, receive_messages, and block_user. The 'notification_view.py' file will define a NotificationView class with methods such as get_notifications and mark_as_read. The 'trend_view.py' file will define a TrendView class with methods such as get_trending_hashtags and get_user_recommendations. After implementing these classes, write tests to ensure that the views render correctly and the user interactions are handled properly.",

    "5. Implement the main application. In the 'main.py' file, import the Flask module and create an instance of the Flask class. Also, import the views and register them with the Flask application. Set up the routes for the different views and the corresponding HTTP methods. For example, the route for the register view might be '/register' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the login view might be '/login' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the reset_password view might be '/reset_password' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the edit_profile view might be '/edit_profile' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the toggle_privacy view might be '/toggle_privacy' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the create_post view might be '/create_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the delete_post view might be '/delete_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the search_posts view might be '/search_posts' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the create_comment view might be '/create_comment' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the delete_comment view might be '/delete_comment' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the like_post view might be '/like_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the unlike_post view might be '/unlike_post' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the follow_user view might be '/follow_user' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the unfollow_user view might be '/unfollow_user' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'DELETE'. The route for the send_message view might be '/send_message' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the receive_messages view might be '/receive_messages' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the block_user view might be '/block_user' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the get_notifications view might be '/get_notifications' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the mark_as_read view might be '/mark_as_read' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'POST'. The route for the get_trending_hashtags view might be '/get_trending_hashtags' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. The route for the get_user_recommendations view might be '/get_user_recommendations' and the corresponding HTTP method might be 'GET'. After setting up the routes, write tests to ensure that the routes work as expected and the HTTP methods are handled properly.",

    "6. Implement the utility functions for the application. In the 'utils' directory, create Python files for each of the following utilities: 'auth.py', 'image.py', 'search.py', 'trend.py', and 'recommend.py'. The 'auth.py' file will define functions for handling authentication, such as generating and verifying JWT tokens. The 'image.py' file will define functions for processing images, such as resizing and cropping. The 'search.py' file will define functions for searching posts and users. The 'trend.py' file will define functions for identifying trending hashtags and topics. The 'recommend.py' file will define functions for recommending users to follow. After implementing these utilities, write tests to ensure that they work as expected.",

    "7. Finally, run the application and perform end-to-end testing. Use the pytest module to run all the tests that have been written. Ensure that all the tests pass. If any tests fail, debug the code and fix the issues. Once all the tests pass, the application is ready for deployment."
  ]
}

sub_messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.
